words.definition: to lower in rank, prestige, or esteem; to humble or degrade
sentences: The scandal served to abase him in the public eye.
She refused to abase herself by apologizing for something she didn't do.

words.definition: to reduce in intensity, amount, or degree
sentences: The storm began to abate after midnight.
Her anger did not abate even after his apology.

words.definition: to give up a position of power or responsibility
sentences: The king chose to abdicate the throne.
He abdicated his duties as team captain.

words.definition: departing from the normal or accepted standard
sentences: His aberrant behavior worried his parents.
The scientist studied the aberrant results carefully.

words.definition: to regard with disgust and hatred
sentences: She abhors violence in any form.
Many people abhor the idea of cruelty to animals.

words.definition: extremely bad, unpleasant, or degrading; completely without pride
sentences: They lived in abject poverty.
His abject failure disappointed everyone.

words.definition: to renounce or reject something desired
sentences: He abnegated his claim to the family fortune.
The monks abnegate worldly pleasures.

words.definition: to abolish or annul by authority
sentences: The government moved to abrogate the treaty.
They abrogated the old rules and created new ones.

words.definition: to leave hurriedly and secretly to escape detection
sentences: The thief absconded with the jewels.
He absconded before the police arrived.

words.definition: to free from blame, guilt, or responsibility
sentences: The jury absolved him of all charges.
She was absolved of any wrongdoing.

words.definition: to restrain oneself from doing something
sentences: He abstained from voting on the issue.
She decided to abstain from eating sweets.

words.definition: existing in thought or as an idea but not concrete
sentences: Justice is an abstract concept.
The painting was too abstract for me to understand.

words.definition: difficult to understand; obscure
sentences: The professor's abstruse lecture confused the students.
The book was filled with abstruse philosophical ideas.

words.definition: enthusiastic public praise or approval
sentences: The film received widespread acclaim.
Her performance won critical acclaim.

words.definition: an award or expression of praise
sentences: She received many accolades for her research.
The highest accolade went to the young scientist.

words.definition: to accept something reluctantly without protest
sentences: She acquiesced to her parents' wishes.
He finally acquiesced and signed the contract.

words.definition: having an unpleasantly sharp or bitter taste or smell
sentences: The acrid smoke filled the room.
An acrid odor came from the burning plastic.

words.definition: bitterness or ill feeling in speech or manner
sentences: The divorce was filled with acrimony.
There was much acrimony between the two rivals.

words.definition: the ability to make good judgments and quick decisions
sentences: Her business acumen led to great success.
He showed political acumen in handling the crisis.

words.definition: refusing to be persuaded or to change one's mind
sentences: She was adamant about not changing the plan.
He remained adamant in his refusal.

words.definition: to warn or reprimand someone firmly
sentences: The teacher admonished the students for being late.
She admonished him to be more careful.

words.definition: clever or skillful in using the hands or mind
sentences: He was adroit at solving complex problems.
Her adroit handling of the situation impressed everyone.

words.definition: excessive admiration or praise
sentences: The celebrity was tired of constant adulation.
His adulation of the author was obvious.

words.definition: an opponent or enemy
sentences: He faced his adversary in the final match.
The two adversaries finally reached an agreement.

words.definition: difficulties or misfortune
sentences: She showed courage in the face of adversity.
They overcame great adversity to succeed.

words.definition: to publicly support or recommend a cause or policy
sentences: She advocates for children's rights.
He advocates a healthier lifestyle.

words.definition: concerned with beauty or the appreciation of beauty
sentences: The room had great aesthetic appeal.
She has strong aesthetic sensibilities.

words.definition: friendly, good-natured, and easy to talk to
sentences: The affable host made everyone feel welcome.
His affable manner put guests at ease.

words.definition: a whole formed by combining several elements
sentences: The aggregate of their scores determined the winner.
An aggregate of small stones formed the path.

words.definition: brisk and cheerful readiness
sentences: She accepted the invitation with alacrity.
He responded to the challenge with alacrity.

words.definition: although; even though
sentences: He accepted the job, albeit reluctantly.
The movie was good, albeit a bit long.

words.definition: to cause someone to feel isolated or estranged
sentences: His rude behavior alienated his friends.
The policy may alienate voters.

words.definition: to make suffering or a problem less severe
sentences: The medicine helped alleviate her pain.
We must find ways to alleviate poverty.

words.definition: showing a selfless concern for the well-being of others
sentences: Her altruistic nature led her to volunteer.
He made an altruistic donation to the charity.

words.definition: to combine or unite to form one organization or structure
sentences: The two companies decided to amalgamate.
They amalgamated their resources for the project.

words.definition: open to more than one interpretation; unclear
sentences: The contract contained ambiguous language.
Her ambiguous response confused everyone.

words.definition: having mixed feelings or contradictory ideas about something
sentences: She felt ambivalent about the job offer.
He was ambivalent about moving to a new city.

words.definition: to make something bad or unsatisfactory better
sentences: The new policy will ameliorate working conditions.
Steps were taken to ameliorate the situation.

words.definition: open and responsive to suggestion; easily persuaded
sentences: She was amenable to the proposed changes.
He proved amenable to our requests.

words.definition: having a friendly and pleasant manner
sentences: The amiable shopkeeper greeted every customer.
She has an amiable personality.

words.definition: characterized by friendliness and absence of discord
sentences: They reached an amicable agreement.
The divorce was surprisingly amicable.

words.definition: without a clearly defined shape or form
sentences: The cloud had an amorphous shape.
His ideas remained amorphous and unclear.

words.definition: enough or more than enough; plentiful
sentences: There was ample food for everyone.
She had ample time to finish the project.

words.definition: comparable in certain respects; similar
sentences: The human brain is analogous to a computer.
Their situations are analogous in many ways.

words.definition: a state of disorder due to absence of authority
sentences: The country fell into anarchy after the coup.
Without rules, the classroom descended into anarchy.

words.definition: strong hostility or hatred
sentences: There was animosity between the two families.
Old animosity still existed between them.

words.definition: something that deviates from what is standard or normal
sentences: The warm weather in December was an anomaly.
Scientists studied the anomaly in the data.

words.definition: to cause someone to become hostile
sentences: His comments only served to antagonize her.
Try not to antagonize your coworkers.

words.definition: a person or thing that is the direct opposite of something else
sentences: His personality is the antithesis of mine.
War is the antithesis of peace.

words.definition: showing or feeling no interest, enthusiasm, or concern
sentences: The students seemed apathetic about the election.
He became apathetic after losing his job.

words.definition: to pacify or placate someone by giving in to their demands
sentences: She tried to appease the angry customer.
The government attempted to appease the protesters.

words.definition: anxious or fearful about something that might happen
sentences: She was apprehensive about the upcoming exam.
He felt apprehensive about meeting new people.

words.definition: based on random choice rather than reason or system
sentences: The decision seemed completely arbitrary.
Arbitrary rules frustrate the workers.

words.definition: understood by few; mysterious or secret
sentences: The arcane rituals fascinated the researcher.
He studied arcane texts from ancient times.

words.definition: very old or old-fashioned
sentences: The law was considered archaic and outdated.
They used archaic language in the ceremony.

words.definition: enthusiastic or passionate
sentences: She was an ardent supporter of the cause.
His ardent love never wavered.

words.definition: involving or requiring strenuous effort; difficult
sentences: The climb up the mountain was arduous.
She faced an arduous journey ahead.

words.definition: able to express thoughts and feelings clearly
sentences: She gave an articulate presentation.
He is very articulate when speaking in public.

words.definition: characterized by severe self-discipline and avoidance of indulgence
sentences: The monk lived an ascetic life.
Her ascetic lifestyle surprised her friends.

words.definition: to direct one's hopes or ambitions toward achieving something
sentences: She aspires to become a doctor.
He aspires to greatness in his field.

words.definition: showing great care and perseverance
sentences: She was assiduous in her studies.
His assiduous efforts paid off.

words.definition: to make an unpleasant feeling less intense
sentences: Nothing could assuage her grief.
He tried to assuage their fears.

words.definition: having or showing sharp powers of judgment
sentences: The astute investor made wise decisions.
She made an astute observation.

words.definition: to gradually decline in effectiveness or vigor
sentences: His muscles began to atrophy from lack of use.
Skills will atrophy without practice.

words.definition: showing a willingness to take bold risks
sentences: Her audacious plan surprised everyone.
He made an audacious move in the chess game.

words.definition: to make something greater by adding to it
sentences: She took a second job to augment her income.
They augmented the team with new members.

words.definition: conducive to success; favorable
sentences: It was an auspicious beginning to the project.
The signs were auspicious for the journey.

words.definition: severe or strict in manner or attitude; plain and simple
sentences: The room had an austere appearance.
He led an austere lifestyle.

words.definition: having the freedom to act independently
sentences: The region sought to become autonomous.
She valued being autonomous in her work.

words.definition: extreme greed for wealth or material gain
sentences: His avarice led to his downfall.
Avarice corrupted the businessman.

words.definition: a strong dislike or disinclination
sentences: She has an aversion to public speaking.
His aversion to crowds kept him home.

words.definition: to give a false impression of something
sentences: Her calm expression belied her inner turmoil.
His age belies his youthful energy.

words.definition: hostile and aggressive; ready to fight
sentences: The belligerent customer demanded to see the manager.
His belligerent attitude made negotiations difficult.

words.definition: to express discontent or sorrow over something
sentences: She bemoaned the loss of her old neighborhood.
He bemoaned his lack of free time.

words.definition: a person who gives money or help to a person or cause
sentences: An anonymous benefactor donated the funds.
The hospital's benefactor was honored at the gala.

words.definition: well-meaning and kindly
sentences: The benevolent king was loved by his people.
She had a benevolent smile.

words.definition: gentle and kindly; not harmful
sentences: The tumor was benign and not cancerous.
He had a benign disposition.

words.definition: to scold or criticize someone angrily
sentences: The coach berated the players for their poor performance.
She berated him for being late.

words.definition: to confer or present an honor, right, or gift
sentences: The queen bestowed knighthood upon him.
Nature bestowed many gifts upon the land.

words.definition: high-sounding but with little meaning; inflated
sentences: His bombastic speech impressed no one.
The politician's bombastic promises rang hollow.

words.definition: rough and bad-mannered; coarse
sentences: His boorish behavior offended the guests.
She was embarrassed by his boorish remarks.

words.definition: bold and without shame
sentences: He made a brazen attempt to cheat on the exam.
Her brazen lie shocked everyone.

words.definition: concise and exact use of words; shortness of time
sentences: The brevity of his speech was appreciated.
She admired the brevity of the poem.

words.definition: to strengthen or support
sentences: He used statistics to buttress his argument.
The evidence buttressed her claims.

words.definition: relating to the pleasant aspects of the countryside
sentences: They enjoyed the bucolic scenery of the farm.
The painting depicted a bucolic landscape.

words.definition: to begin to grow or increase rapidly
sentences: The city's population began to burgeon.
Her interest in art burgeoned during college.

words.definition: a harsh, discordant mixture of sounds
sentences: The cacophony of car horns filled the street.
The orchestra's cacophony made everyone cringe.

words.definition: to persuade someone to do something by flattery or gentle urging
sentences: She cajoled him into lending her money.
He cajoled his way into the exclusive party.

words.definition: mutual trust and friendship among people who spend time together
sentences: There was great camaraderie among the teammates.
The camaraderie in the office made work enjoyable.

words.definition: truthful and straightforward; frank
sentences: She gave a candid assessment of the situation.
I appreciate your candid opinion.

words.definition: having a lot of space inside; roomy
sentences: The capacious bag held all her belongings.
They moved into a capacious apartment.

words.definition: given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood
sentences: The capricious weather made planning difficult.
Her capricious nature kept everyone guessing.

words.definition: to reprimand someone severely
sentences: The manager castigated the employee for the error.
Critics castigated the film for its inaccuracies.

words.definition: a person or thing that precipitates an event or change
sentences: Her speech was a catalyst for change.
The discovery served as a catalyst for further research.

words.definition: sarcastic in a scathing and bitter way
sentences: His caustic remarks hurt her feelings.
The review was caustic and unfair.

words.definition: to express severe disapproval of someone or something
sentences: The committee voted to censure the senator.
He was censured for his unethical behavior.

words.definition: a person falsely claiming to have special knowledge or skill
sentences: The so-called healer was exposed as a charlatan.
Don't trust that charlatan's promises.

words.definition: to rebuke or reprimand severely
sentences: The teacher chastised the students for cheating.
She chastised herself for the mistake.

words.definition: the use of trickery to achieve a goal
sentences: The contract was obtained through chicanery.
Political chicanery undermined public trust.

words.definition: longer than the most direct way; roundabout
sentences: They took a circuitous route to avoid traffic.
His explanation was circuitous and confusing.

words.definition: to restrict something within limits
sentences: His authority was circumscribed by the board.
Budget constraints circumscribe our options.

words.definition: wary and unwilling to take risks
sentences: She was circumspect in her dealings with strangers.
A circumspect approach is advised.

words.definition: kept secret or done secretively
sentences: They held clandestine meetings after dark.
The clandestine operation was never discovered.

words.definition: mercy; lenience
sentences: The prisoner appealed for clemency.
The judge showed clemency in his sentencing.

words.definition: to come together and form one mass or whole
sentences: The groups coalesced to form a single organization.
Their ideas coalesced into a unified plan.

words.definition: to persuade someone by using force or threats
sentences: He was coerced into signing the document.
They coerced witnesses to change their testimony.

words.definition: clear, logical, and convincing
sentences: She presented a cogent argument for the proposal.
His cogent reasoning won the debate.

words.definition: logical and consistent; forming a unified whole
sentences: The witness gave a coherent account of events.
Her essay was well-organized and coherent.

words.definition: used in ordinary or familiar conversation
sentences: The author used colloquial language in the dialogue.
His colloquial speech made him relatable.

words.definition: corresponding in size or degree; proportionate
sentences: Salary should be commensurate with experience.
The punishment was commensurate with the crime.

words.definition: evoking interest or attention in an irresistible way
sentences: She made a compelling case for reform.
The novel had a compelling storyline.

words.definition: showing smug or uncritical satisfaction with oneself
sentences: Success made him complacent about his work.
We cannot afford to be complacent about safety.

words.definition: something that completes or makes perfect
sentences: The wine was a perfect complement to the meal.
Her skills are a complement to his.

words.definition: inclined to agree with others or obey rules
sentences: The company became compliant with regulations.
He was compliant with the doctor's orders.

words.definition: to admit that something is true after first denying it
sentences: He conceded that he had made a mistake.
She conceded defeat gracefully.

words.definition: intended to placate or pacify
sentences: He made a conciliatory gesture toward his opponent.
Her conciliatory tone eased the tension.

words.definition: serving to prove a case; decisive
sentences: The evidence was conclusive.
No conclusive proof was found.

words.definition: naturally accompanying or associated
sentences: The concomitant rise in prices affected everyone.
Stress and its concomitant health problems are concerning.

words.definition: agreement or harmony between people or groups
sentences: The treaty established concord between the nations.
They worked in concord to achieve their goal.

words.definition: to show patronizing superiority toward someone
sentences: She condescended to speak to the new employee.
Don't condescend to me about finances.

words.definition: to accept and allow behavior that is considered wrong
sentences: The school does not condone bullying.
She could not condone his dishonesty.

words.definition: making a certain situation or outcome likely or possible
sentences: The quiet environment was conducive to studying.
Good nutrition is conducive to health.

words.definition: a large and destructive fire
sentences: The conflagration destroyed several buildings.
Firefighters battled the conflagration for hours.

words.definition: to cause surprise or confusion
sentences: The puzzle confounded even the experts.
His behavior confounded his friends.

words.definition: pleasant because of qualities similar to one's own
sentences: She found a congenial group of friends.
The congenial atmosphere put everyone at ease.

words.definition: an opinion or conclusion based on incomplete information
sentences: His theory was based on conjecture, not fact.
We can only conjecture about what happened.

words.definition: wishing to do what is right; careful and thorough
sentences: She was a conscientious student.
His conscientious work ethic impressed his boss.

words.definition: general agreement among a group
sentences: The committee reached a consensus.
There was no consensus on the issue.

words.definition: to comfort someone at a time of grief or disappointment
sentences: She tried to console her crying friend.
Nothing could console him after the loss.

words.definition: standing out so as to be clearly visible
sentences: His absence was conspicuous at the meeting.
The red car was conspicuous in the parking lot.

words.definition: showing great skill and flair; complete or perfect
sentences: She was a consummate professional.
He handled it with consummate ease.

words.definition: the feeling that someone or something is worthless
sentences: She looked at him with contempt.
He held the corrupt politicians in contempt.

words.definition: causing or likely to cause disagreement
sentences: The issue remains highly contentious.
They avoided the contentious topic.

words.definition: feeling or expressing remorse for wrongdoing
sentences: He was contrite about his behavior.
Her contrite apology was accepted.

words.definition: a way in which something is usually done
sentences: She followed the conventions of formal letter writing.
Social conventions vary by culture.

words.definition: extremely complex and difficult to follow
sentences: The plot of the movie was convoluted.
His explanation was too convoluted to understand.

words.definition: abundant in supply or quantity
sentences: She took copious notes during the lecture.
The garden produced copious amounts of vegetables.

words.definition: warm and friendly
sentences: They received a cordial welcome.
The meeting was cordial but brief.

words.definition: to confirm or give support to a statement or theory
sentences: Witnesses corroborated her story.
The evidence corroborates the hypothesis.

words.definition: not openly acknowledged or displayed
sentences: The covert operation was highly classified.
He gave her a covert glance.

words.definition: having or showing too great a readiness to believe things
sentences: The credulous investors fell for the scam.
She was too credulous to doubt his story.

words.definition: to reach the highest or final point
sentences: The festival culminated in a fireworks display.
Years of work culminated in success.

words.definition: deserving blame
sentences: He was culpable for the accident.
The company was found culpable of negligence.

words.definition: hasty and therefore not thorough or detailed
sentences: He gave the document only a cursory glance.
A cursory examination revealed nothing unusual.

words.definition: to reduce in extent or quantity
sentences: Budget cuts curtailed the program.
We need to curtail our spending.

words.definition: a person who believes that people are motivated purely by self-interest
sentences: The cynic doubted everyone's motives.
Don't be such a cynic about human nature.

words.definition: to make someone feel intimidated or discouraged
sentences: The challenge did not daunt her.
He was daunted by the size of the task.

words.definition: to make someone weak or infirm
sentences: The illness debilitated him for months.
Lack of sleep can debilitate your body.

words.definition: behavior in keeping with good taste and propriety
sentences: She maintained perfect decorum at the funeral.
The students showed no sense of decorum.

words.definition: the action of damaging someone's reputation
sentences: He sued the newspaper for defamation.
The article was full of defamation.

words.definition: humble submission and respect
sentences: He treated his elders with deference.
In deference to her wishes, we stayed home.

words.definition: neatly skillful and quick in one's movements
sentences: She handled the situation with deft diplomacy.
His deft fingers quickly tied the knot.

words.definition: no longer existing or functioning
sentences: The defunct company left many debts.
They visited the site of the defunct factory.

words.definition: to treat someone with disrespect or lower their dignity
sentences: She refused to degrade herself by responding to insults.
Pollution degrades the environment.

words.definition: causing harm or damage
sentences: Smoking has deleterious effects on health.
The deleterious impact was immediate.

words.definition: to describe or portray something precisely
sentences: The report delineated the problem clearly.
She delineated her plan in detail.

words.definition: to publicly declare to be wrong or evil
sentences: She denounced the government's policies.
Leaders denounced the violent protests.

words.definition: to use up the supply or resources of
sentences: Overfishing depletes ocean populations.
The long journey depleted their energy.

words.definition: to feel or express strong disapproval of
sentences: She deplored the lack of funding for schools.
They deplored the violence in the streets.

words.definition: to express disapproval of
sentences: He deprecated the use of outdated methods.
She deprecated his reckless behavior.

words.definition: to express contempt for; to ridicule
sentences: Critics derided the movie as shallow.
He derided her efforts as worthless.

words.definition: imitative of the work of another person
sentences: The novel was criticized as derivative.
His music was derivative of earlier artists.

words.definition: in low spirits from loss of hope or courage
sentences: He became despondent after losing his job.
She felt despondent about the future.

words.definition: a ruler who holds absolute power, typically one who exercises it cruelly
sentences: The despot ruled with an iron fist.
The people overthrew the cruel despot.

words.definition: without the basic necessities of life; extremely poor
sentences: The earthquake left thousands destitute.
The charity helps destitute families.

words.definition: to discourage someone from doing something
sentences: The high price deterred many buyers.
Nothing could deter her from her goal.

words.definition: to diminish the worth or value of something
sentences: The stain detracted from the painting's beauty.
Don't let small flaws detract from your work.

words.definition: to depart from an established course
sentences: She never deviated from her principles.
The driver deviated from the planned route.

words.definition: entirely lacking or free from
sentences: The room was devoid of furniture.
His speech was devoid of emotion.

words.definition: showing or having skill, especially with the hands
sentences: The surgeon was dexterous with the scalpel.
Her dexterous handling of the issue impressed everyone.

words.definition: intended to teach or instruct, especially morally
sentences: The novel had a didactic tone.
His didactic approach annoyed the students.

words.definition: modest or shy because of a lack of self-confidence
sentences: She was diffident about her singing abilities.
His diffident manner made him seem aloof.

words.definition: to leave the main subject temporarily
sentences: The professor often digressed during lectures.
Let me digress for a moment to explain.

words.definition: in a state of disrepair due to age or neglect
sentences: They bought a dilapidated old house.
The dilapidated building was unsafe.

words.definition: having or showing care and conscientiousness in one's work
sentences: She was a diligent student.
His diligent efforts paid off.

words.definition: to make or become less
sentences: The pain began to diminish.
Time did not diminish his love for her.

words.definition: to perceive or recognize something
sentences: It was hard to discern her true feelings.
He could discern the outline in the fog.

words.definition: disagreeing or incongruous; harsh in sound
sentences: The discordant sounds hurt their ears.
Their views were completely discordant.

words.definition: to harm the reputation or respect of someone
sentences: The scandal discredited the politician.
They tried to discredit the witness.

words.definition: a lack of compatibility between two or more facts
sentences: There was a discrepancy in the accounts.
The discrepancy between his words and actions was obvious.

words.definition: the feeling that someone is unworthy of consideration
sentences: She looked at him with disdain.
He expressed disdain for the proposal.

words.definition: to regard or represent as being of little worth
sentences: She disparaged his efforts constantly.
Critics disparaged the new policy.

words.definition: essentially different in kind; not able to be compared
sentences: The two cultures were disparate in nature.
They tried to unite disparate groups.

words.definition: to spread information widely
sentences: The internet helps disseminate information quickly.
They disseminated the news to all employees.

words.definition: the expression of opinions at variance with commonly held ones
sentences: Political dissent was not tolerated.
She voiced her dissent at the meeting.

words.definition: a lack of harmony or agreement
sentences: There was dissonance between the two reports.
The cognitive dissonance troubled her.

words.definition: to separate and go in different directions
sentences: The paths diverged in the woods.
Their opinions diverged on the issue.

words.definition: ready to accept control or instruction; submissive
sentences: The docile horse was easy to train.
The students were surprisingly docile.

words.definition: inclined to lay down principles as undeniably true
sentences: His dogmatic approach alienated colleagues.
She was dogmatic about her beliefs.

words.definition: temporarily inactive; in a state of rest
sentences: The volcano had been dormant for centuries.
The seeds remained dormant until spring.

words.definition: hesitating or doubting; of questionable value
sentences: She was dubious about his claims.
The information came from a dubious source.

words.definition: deceitfulness; double-dealing
sentences: His duplicity was eventually exposed.
She could not tolerate his duplicity.

words.definition: cheerful and full of energy
sentences: Her ebullient personality brightened the room.
He was in an ebullient mood after the victory.

words.definition: unconventional and slightly strange
sentences: The eccentric artist lived in a treehouse.
Her eccentric habits amused her neighbors.

words.definition: deriving ideas or style from a broad range of sources
sentences: Her eclectic taste in music surprised everyone.
The restaurant offered an eclectic menu.

words.definition: to erase or make oneself appear insignificant
sentences: Time had effaced the inscription.
She tried to efface herself in the crowd.

words.definition: the ability to produce a desired result
sentences: Doctors debated the efficacy of the treatment.
The efficacy of the vaccine was proven.

words.definition: insolent or impertinent behavior
sentences: He had the effrontery to demand a raise.
Her effrontery shocked the committee.

words.definition: believing in or based on the principle of equality
sentences: They advocated for an egalitarian society.
The company had egalitarian policies.

words.definition: outstandingly bad; shocking
sentences: The error was egregious and unforgivable.
His egregious behavior led to his dismissal.

words.definition: involving many carefully arranged parts or details
sentences: They planned an elaborate wedding.
Her elaborate explanation confused everyone.

words.definition: ecstatically happy
sentences: She was elated when she got the job.
The team was elated after winning the championship.

words.definition: to draw out a response or fact from someone
sentences: The question elicited an angry response.
He tried to elicit information from the witness.

words.definition: fluent or persuasive in speaking or writing
sentences: She gave an eloquent speech.
His eloquent words moved the audience.

words.definition: to make something clear; explain
sentences: Could you elucidate your point?
The teacher elucidated the complex concept.

words.definition: difficult to find, catch, or achieve
sentences: Success remained elusive for years.
The elusive butterfly escaped capture.

words.definition: to set free from legal, social, or political restrictions
sentences: The proclamation emancipated the slaves.
She felt emancipated after leaving home.

words.definition: to make more attractive by adding details
sentences: He embellished the story to make it more exciting.
She embellished the dress with lace.

words.definition: famous and respected within a particular sphere
sentences: She is an eminent scientist.
The eminent professor gave a lecture.

words.definition: the ability to understand and share the feelings of another
sentences: She showed great empathy for the victims.
Empathy is essential for good relationships.

words.definition: based on observation or experience rather than theory
sentences: The study provided empirical evidence.
Empirical research supports the hypothesis.

words.definition: to match or surpass by imitation
sentences: He tried to emulate his mentor's success.
The software emulates the original system.

words.definition: native and restricted to a certain place
sentences: The species is endemic to the island.
Corruption was endemic in the organization.

words.definition: to cause someone to feel drained of energy
sentences: The heat enervated the workers.
The long illness enervated her completely.

words.definition: to cause or give rise to
sentences: The policy engendered much controversy.
Her kindness engendered trust.

words.definition: to intensify, increase, or further improve quality
sentences: The renovation enhanced the property's value.
Good lighting enhances the painting.

words.definition: a person or thing that is mysterious or difficult to understand
sentences: She remained an enigma to her colleagues.
The disappearance is still an enigma.

words.definition: the state of being actively opposed or hostile
sentences: There was enmity between the two nations.
Old enmity prevented cooperation.

words.definition: to mention a number of things one by one
sentences: He enumerated the reasons for his decision.
Let me enumerate the steps involved.

words.definition: lasting for a very short time
sentences: Fame can be ephemeral.
The ephemeral beauty of the sunset amazed her.

words.definition: a person or thing that is a perfect example of a quality
sentences: She was the epitome of grace.
The building is the epitome of modern design.

words.definition: mental calmness and composure, especially in difficult situations
sentences: She accepted the news with equanimity.
His equanimity under pressure was admirable.

words.definition: open to more than one interpretation; ambiguous
sentences: His answer was equivocal and evasive.
The results were equivocal.

words.definition: to destroy completely; put an end to
sentences: They hope to eradicate the disease.
Efforts to eradicate poverty continue.

words.definition: not even or regular in pattern; unpredictable
sentences: His erratic behavior worried his friends.
The erratic weather disrupted plans.

words.definition: having or showing great knowledge or learning
sentences: The erudite professor impressed the students.
Her erudite comments enriched the discussion.

words.definition: to deliberately avoid using or participating in
sentences: He eschewed all forms of violence.
She eschewed fast food for health reasons.

words.definition: intended for or understood by only a small number of people
sentences: The book dealt with esoteric subjects.
His esoteric knowledge was impressive.

words.definition: to adopt or support a cause or belief
sentences: She espoused the cause of human rights.
The party espoused progressive policies.

words.definition: extremely delicate and light; heavenly
sentences: The dancer had an ethereal quality.
Ethereal music filled the cathedral.

words.definition: a speech praising someone who has recently died
sentences: He delivered a moving eulogy.
The eulogy honored her life achievements.

words.definition: a mild expression substituted for one considered too harsh
sentences: 'Passed away' is a euphemism for 'died.'
She used euphemisms to soften the bad news.

words.definition: to make a problem or situation worse
sentences: The drought exacerbated the food shortage.
His comments only exacerbated the conflict.

words.definition: making great demands on one's skill or resources
sentences: The job was exacting and stressful.
She had exacting standards for her work.

words.definition: to hold someone or something in very high regard
sentences: They exalted her as a hero.
The song exalts the beauty of nature.

words.definition: to irritate and frustrate intensely
sentences: His constant questions exasperated her.
The delays exasperated the passengers.

words.definition: serving as a desirable model; representing the best
sentences: Her conduct was exemplary.
He received an award for exemplary service.

words.definition: examining or including all elements; thorough
sentences: They conducted an exhaustive search.
The report was exhaustive in its detail.

words.definition: to make someone feel very happy and excited
sentences: The news exhilarated the team.
The ride exhilarated the children.

words.definition: to absolve someone from blame or fault
sentences: New evidence exonerated the defendant.
He was exonerated of all charges.

words.definition: convenient and practical, though possibly improper
sentences: It was expedient to ignore the problem.
The expedient solution was not ideal.

words.definition: to make an action or process happen sooner
sentences: We must expedite the shipping process.
Extra staff helped expedite the work.

words.definition: stated clearly and in detail, leaving no room for confusion
sentences: The instructions were explicit.
She gave explicit directions to the house.

words.definition: to make full use of a resource; to use unfairly
sentences: The company exploited the workers.
They exploited the natural resources.

words.definition: irrelevant or unrelated to the subject
sentences: Remove all extraneous details from the report.
The noise was extraneous to the experiment.

words.definition: to praise enthusiastically
sentences: Critics extolled the virtues of the film.
She extolled his achievements publicly.

words.definition: filled with lively energy and excitement
sentences: The children were exuberant at the party.
Her exuberant personality was contagious.

words.definition: to invent false information; to construct or manufacture
sentences: He fabricated an alibi.
The parts were fabricated in the factory.

words.definition: treating serious issues with deliberately inappropriate humor
sentences: His facetious remarks annoyed her.
She made a facetious comment about the situation.

words.definition: to make an action or process easier
sentences: Technology facilitates communication.
Her guidance facilitated our success.

words.definition: based on a mistaken belief
sentences: His argument was fallacious.
The fallacious theory was soon disproven.

words.definition: very attentive to accuracy and detail
sentences: She was fastidious about her appearance.
The fastidious editor caught every error.

words.definition: to understand something after much thought
sentences: I cannot fathom why he left.
She tried to fathom the meaning of the poem.

words.definition: silly and pointless
sentences: His fatuous comments wasted everyone's time.
The fatuous plan was doomed to fail.

words.definition: to give a servile display of affection
sentences: The assistant fawned over the celebrity.
He fawned to win the boss's favor.

words.definition: possible to do easily or conveniently
sentences: The plan is financially feasible.
Is it feasible to complete this by Friday?

words.definition: lacking initiative or strength of character; irresponsible
sentences: The feckless employee was fired.
His feckless approach doomed the project.

words.definition: producing or capable of producing an abundance of offspring or vegetation
sentences: The fecund soil produced abundant crops.
Her fecund imagination created endless stories.

words.definition: having or displaying passionate intensity
sentences: She made a fervent plea for help.
His fervent belief never wavered.

words.definition: changing frequently, especially regarding loyalties or affections
sentences: The fickle weather ruined the picnic.
Public opinion can be fickle.

words.definition: conspicuously or obviously offensive
sentences: It was a flagrant violation of the rules.
His flagrant disregard for safety was dangerous.

words.definition: to openly disregard a rule or convention
sentences: He flouted the dress code.
They flouted tradition by eloping.

words.definition: to instigate or stir up an undesirable sentiment or course of action
sentences: The speech was meant to foment rebellion.
They accused him of fomenting unrest.

words.definition: patient self-control; restraint and tolerance
sentences: She showed great forbearance during the trial.
His forbearance impressed the mediator.

words.definition: to prevent or obstruct by taking action in advance
sentences: They tried to forestall the crisis.
Quick action forestalled a disaster.

words.definition: inspiring fear or respect through being impressively powerful
sentences: She faced a formidable opponent.
The task ahead was formidable.

words.definition: to abandon or renounce
sentences: He would never forsake his principles.
She forsook her career for her family.

words.definition: happening by accident or chance rather than design
sentences: Their meeting was entirely fortuitous.
A fortuitous discovery led to the breakthrough.

words.definition: to encourage or promote the development of something
sentences: The program fosters creativity in children.
They foster a sense of community.

words.definition: irritable and quarrelsome
sentences: The fractious child refused to cooperate.
The meeting became fractious.

words.definition: sparing or economical with regard to money or resources
sentences: She led a frugal lifestyle.
Frugal spending helped them save money.

words.definition: attempting to avoid notice or attention; secretive
sentences: He cast a furtive glance around the room.
Her furtive behavior aroused suspicion.
